WERNOCKE.</br>WILLY, why lig'st thou (man) so wo-be-gon?</br>What?  been thy rather Lamkins ill-apaid?</br>Or, hath some drerie chance thy Pipe misdone?</br>Or, hast thou any sheep-cure mis-assaid?</br>Or, is some conteck 'twixt thy love and thee?</br>Or, else some love-warke arsie-varsie tane?</br>Or, fates lesse frolicke than they wont to be?</br>What gars my WILLY that he so doth wane?</br>If it be for thou hast mis-said, or done,</br>Take keepe of thine owne councell; and, thou art</br>As sheene and cleare fro both-twaine as the Sunne:</br>For all Swaines laud thine haviour, and thine Art.</br>Ma hap thine heart (that unneath brooke neglect,</br>And jealous of thy fresh fame) liggs upon</br>Thy rurall songs, which rarest Clarkes affect,</br>Dreading the descant that mote fall thereon.</br>Droope not for that (man) but unpleate thy browes,</br>And blithly, so, fold envies up in pleats:</br>For, fro thy Makings milke, and mellie, flowes</br>To feed the Songster-swains with Arts soot-meats.
WILLIE.</br>Now, siker (Wernocke) thou hast split the marke</br>Albe that I ne wot I han mis-song:</br>But, for I am so yong, I dread my warke</br>Woll he misvalued both of old and yong.

WERNOCKE.</br>Is thilke the cause that thou been ligge so laid,</br>Who whilom no encheson could fore-haile;</br>And caitive courage nere made misapaid,</br>But with chiefe yongsters songsters bar'st thy saile?</br>As swoot as Swans thy straines make Thames to ring</br>Fro Cotswould where her sourse her course doth take,</br>To her wide mouth which vents thy carolling</br>Beyond the hether and the further lake.</br>Than up (sad swaine) pull fro thy vailed cheeke</br>Hur prop, thy palme:  and let thy Virilaies,</br>Kill envious cunning swaines (whom all do seeke)</br>With envy, at thine earned gaudy praise.</br>Up lither lad, thou reck'st much of thy swinke,</br>When swinke ne swat thou should'st ne reck for fame;</br>At Aganip than, lay thee downe to drinke</br>Untill thy stomacke swell, to raise thy name.</br>What though time yet han not bedowld thy Chin?</br>Thy Dams deere wombe was Helicon to thee;</br>Where (like a Loach) thou drew'st thilke liquor in,</br>Which on thy heart-strings ran with musickes glee.</br>Than up betimes, and make the sullen swaines</br>With thy shrill Reed such jolly-jovisance</br>That they (entranc'd) ma wonder at thy straines;</br>So, leave of thee ne're ending sovenance.

WILLIE.</br>Ah Wernocke, Wernocke, so my sp'rits been steept</br>In dulnesse, through these duller times missawes</br>Of sik-like musicke (riming rudely cleept.)</br>That yer I pipe well, must be better cause.</br>Ah, who (with lavish draughts of Aganip)</br>Can swill their soule to frolick; so, their Muse,</br>Whan Courts and Camps, that erst the muse did clip,</br>Do now forlore her; nay, her most abuse?</br>Now, with their witlesse, causelesse surquedry</br>They been transpos'd fro what of yore they were,</br>That Swaines, who but to looser luxurie</br>Can shew the way, are now most cherisht there.</br>These times been crimefull (ah) and being so,</br>Bold Swaines (deft Songsters) sing them criminall;</br>So, make themselves oft gleefull in their woe:</br>For thy tho Songsters are misween'd of all.</br>Mecaenas woont in blonket liveries</br>Yclad sike chanters; but these miser times</br>Uncase hem quite, that all may hem despise,</br>As they don all their best embellisht Rimes.</br>And Harvest-queenes, of yore, would Chaplets make</br>To crowne their scalpes that couth most swootly sing,</br>And give hem many a gaude at Ale or Wake:</br>But now ne recke they of soot carrolling.</br>Enaunter they should be as seeme they would,</br>Or songen lowdly for so deere desart;</br>Or else be peregall to Nymphes of old,</br>From which their beastlihed now freely start.</br>Than must they latch the blowes of Fates too fell,</br>With their too feeble clowches as they con:</br>For none regards, or guards hem for their spell,</br>Tho they, on point-device, empt Helicon!</br>There nis thilke chivisance they whilome had</br>For piping swoote; sith, with an Heydeguies,</br>Pipt by Tom-piper, or a Lorrel-lad,</br>(So be he clawes hem) they idolatrize.</br>And those that should presse proper songs for sale</br>Bene, in their doomes, so dull; in skill, so crude;</br>That they had leaver printen Jacke a vale</br>Or Clim O Clough (alacke) they beene so rude!</br>And sith so few feate Songsters in an age</br>Bene founden, few do weigh hem as they been;</br>For, Swaines, that con no skill of holy-rage</br>Bene foe-men to faire skils enlawrel'd Queen.</br>Enough is mee, for thy, that I ma vent</br>My wits spels to my selfe, or unto thee</br>(Deer Wernock) which dost feel like miscontent</br>Sith thou, and all unheeded, singt with mee.

WERNOCKE.</br>Vartue it's sed (and is an old said-saw)</br>Is for hur selfe, to be forsought alone:</br>Then eftsoones fro their case thy shrill pipes draw</br>And make the welkin ringen with their tone.</br>Of world, ne worly men take thou no keepe</br>What the one doth, or what the other say;</br>For should I so, I so, should Eyne out-weepe:</br>Than, with mee; Willy, ay sing care-away.</br>It's wood to be fore-pinde with wastefull carke</br>In many a noyfull stoure of willing bale,</br>For vading toyes:  But trim wits poorest wark</br>The upper heav'n han hent fro nether Dale.</br>Thilks all our share of all the quelling heape</br>Of this world's good:  enough is us to tell</br>How rude the rest bene, caduke, and how cheape;</br>But, laude for well done warks, don all excell!</br>For thy we shoulden take keepe of our Race</br>That here wee rennen, and what here we doon</br>That whan wee wenden till an other place,</br>Our sovenance may here, ay-gayly wonne.</br>For, time will underfong us; and our voice</br>Woll woxon weake; and, our devising lame;</br>For, life is brief; and skils beene long, and choise:</br>Than, spend we Time, that Time may spare our Fame.</br>Look how breme Winter chamfers Earth's bleeke face</br>So, corbed Eld accoyes youths surquedry;</br>And, in the front, deepe furrowes doon enchase,</br>Inveloped with falling snow a hy.</br>Then nought can be atchiev'd with witty shewes,</br>Sith Briefe of Elde accloyen wimble wit;</br>Than, us behoven, yer Elde sick accrewes,</br>Time to forelay, with spells retarding it.</br>I 'not what blisse is whelm'd with heav'n's coape</br>So bee the pleasance of the Muse be none:</br>For, when thilk gleesome joyes han hallowed scope</br>They beene as those that heav'ns-folke warble on.</br>I con my good; for, now my scalpe is frost</br>Yeelding to snow; the crow-feete neere mine Eyne</br>Beene markes of mickle preefe I have, that most</br>Of all glees else alow, han suddaine fine.</br>O how it garres old Wernork swynck with glee</br>In that emprise that chiven featest fame!</br>It heats my heart above ability</br>To leave parduring sovenance of my name.</br>And whan mine Engine han heav'd hy my thought,</br>And that on point-device eftsoones y fell</br>O!  how my heart's joy-rapt, as I had cought,</br>A Princedome to my share, of thilk Newell.</br>They beene of pleasaunces the alderbest:</br>Than, God to forne; I wol no mo but tho:</br>Tho beene the summe of all I loven best:</br>And for hem love I life; else nold I so.</br>Drive on thy flocke than, to the motley plaines</br>Where by some prill, that 'mong the Pibbles plods,</br>Thou, with thyne Oaten reede, and queintest straines,</br>Maist rapt the senior Swaines, and minor Gods:</br>That as on Ida that mych-famed Mount,</br>A Shepheard Swaine; that sung lesse soote than thou</br>By light loves Goddesse, had the grace to mount</br>To owe the sheenest Queene that earth did owe:</br>So, thou maiest, with thy past'rall Minstralsy</br>Beating the aire, atweene resounding Hils,</br>Draw to thee Bonibels as smirke, as hy,</br>And wrap hem in thy love begrey their wils:</br>For (ah) had Phoebus Clarkes the meanes of some</br>Worse Clarkes (paravnter) so to sing at ease;</br>They soone would make high long-wing'd haggards come;</br>And vaile unto their Lures:  so, on hem seise.</br>For, bright Nymphes buxome Breastes do eas'ly ope</br>To let in thirling notes of noted laies:</br>For, deftly song they han a charming scope;</br>So, Nymphs themselves adore Brows girt with Bayes.</br>Than, Willy (ah for pitty of thine heart</br>That drouping yearnes, at misses of these times)</br>Take thou thy Pipe, and of glee take thy part;</br>Or cheere thy selfe with cordials of thy Rimes.</br>Before the world's sterne face, the world backe-bite</br>So slyly that her parts ne' it perceive:</br>Morall thy matter so, that, tho thou smite,</br>Thou maist with tickling her dull sence, deceive.</br>Then hy thee, Willy, to the neighhour wasts</br>Where thou (as in another world alone)</br>Maist (while thy flocke do feede) blow bitter blasts</br>On thy loudst Pipe, to make il's pertly knowne.</br>For, sith the rude-crude world doon us misplease</br>That well deserven, tell wee her hur owne;</br>And let her ken our cunning can, with ease,</br>Aye shend, or lend hur sempiterne renowne.

WILLIE.</br>Ah Wernocke, so thy sawes mine heart downe thril</br>With love of Muses skill in speciall,</br>That I ne wot, on mould what feater skill</br>Can bee yhugg'd in Lordings pectorall.</br>Ne would I it let-bee for all the store</br>In th' uncoth scope of both-twain hemispheres;</br>Ynough is mee, perdy, nor strive for more</br>But to be rich in hery for my leeres.</br>Ne would I sharen that soule-gladding glee</br>In th' ever gaudy Gardens of the blest</br>Not there to han the Muses companee,</br>Which, God to-fore, is of the best, the best.</br>Now, Wernock, shalt thou see (so mote I thee)</br>That I nill usen any skill so mytch</br>(Faire fall my swinck) as this so nice, and free,</br>In case I may my name to Heaven stitch.</br>For why; I am by kind so inly pulde</br>To these delices; that when I betake</br>My selfe to other lore I more am dul'd;</br>And therefro, keenely set, I fall to make.</br>But, well-away, thy nis the way to thriven;</br>And, my neer kith, for that wol sore me shend:</br>Who little reck how I by kind am given;</br>But hur wold force to swinck for thriftier end.</br>Hence forward then I must assay, and con</br>My leere in leeful lore, to pleasen them</br>That, sib to mee, would my promotion,</br>And carke for that to prancke our common Stemme:</br>For, now (as wends the world) no skill to that</br>(Or rather but that) thrives; sith Swaines are now</br>So full of contecke, that they wot ne what</br>They would; so, if they could; they all would owe.</br>So fares it in calme seasons with curst men;</br>If frennes forbeare, at home, hem to invade,</br>They wry their peace to noy each other then</br>By plees, till they decease, or fall, or fade.</br>So times beene keener now with common Swaynes;</br>Than whan as forraigne foe-men with hem fought:</br>For, now they swyncke, but for slye Law-mens gaines</br>Or seld they should possessen what they ought.</br>But, what for this?  to mee it little longs</br>To gab of sikliche notes of misery;</br>Ynough is mee to chaunten swoote my songs,</br>And blend hem with my rurall mynstrelsy.</br>But, O (my Wernock) how am I to thee</br>Obligen, for thy keene reencouragements</br>To skill, so mickle lov'd and sought of mee</br>As this of making with Arts Elements?</br>I not how I shall thrive therein; ne how</br>I shall be dempt of in these nicer times:</br>But how soere so thou my workes alow,</br>I nill bee ill-apaiden with my Rimes.

WERNOCKE.</br>Thou nedst not, Willy; wretch were I to laude</br>Thee in thy misses:  for, I so should bee</br>To th' adultries of thy wits-scapes, but a Baude,</br>Ne, as a friend, in sentence, should bee free.</br>Than, wend thou fairely on, with thyne emprise;</br>Sing cleerely, Willy, on mine encouragement,</br>And other Swaines, more able to devise;</br>And, fixe thee for it, in the firmament.</br>Ynough is mee so I may beare a part</br>Aye in the Muses Quire with those and thee;</br>Il'e sing (at ease) aloud, with cheerefull hart,</br>No base, ne meane, but Tenor of best glee.

WILLIE.</br>And I, with thee, woll chaunt each counter-verse</br>So shrilly that wee'l make thilk Quire to ring</br>As ever do the Angels; who rehearse</br>The loudest lauds of heav'ns-Lord whan they sing.</br>So, farewell, Wernock, mickle thankes to thee</br>For thy freedome, that canst so well devise:</br>Phoebus now goes to glade; than now goe wee,</br>Unto our sheddes to rest us till he rise.
WERNOCKE.</br>Agree'd deere, Willy, gent and debonaire,</br>Wee'l hence:  for, rhumaticke now fares the Aire.</br>
